ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: complex analysis.
Most of chapters 1-7 of Gamelin.
Basic complex analysis. Analytic/holomorphic functions, Cauchy's theorem/integral formula, basics on harmonic functions and conformal mappings. Laurent series and decomposition, residue theorem.

I learned more about complex numbers, complex functions, complex differentiability and the Cauchy Riemann equations, complex integration and various theorems relating to integration, power series, Laurent series, and the Residue Theorem.
First 7 chapters of Gamelin
Recap of the algebra of C, basic analysis in C. Complex limits, differentiation, analyticity, integrals, power series, Laurent series.
We did up to section VII.3 of Gamelin's textbook, though I didn't end up feeling terribly comfortable with all of it.

Quite a bit of complex analysis. The results are really interesting and quite different from the stuff Id seen before. It seems like complex analysis is done a bit differently than real analysis in that there are less delta epsilon/technical proofs involved. Its slightly more direct in my opinion.
Fundamental theorems in complex analysis
This class covers complex analysis topics including basic complex number stuff, complex differentiation and analyticity, complex line integrals, and the residue theorem.

We started with complex number arithmetic. Then we moved on to several topics and definitions that are similar to real analysis. Starting with the Cauchy-Riemann equations halfway through the semester, we learned things that make complex analysis unique. Light exposure to several topics in this large area of math.
Standard introductory topics in complex analysis, up to the residue theorem
I learned a lot about complex analysis, worked on some general multivariable calculus techniques, and got better at writing proofs.
Complex functions, differentiation, and integration techniques.
Cauchy integral formula
I developed a foundation in complex analysis (including basics, the Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic continuation, and residue calculus).

concepts: complex numbers and their properties, complex functions and conformal mappings, differentiation with complex numbers, MANY theorems (residual theorems, cauchy theorems, etc.)

skills/insights: mostly application-based problems, lots of visual learning (e.g. using Riemann surface, graphs of power functions, etc.)

An intro to complex analysis: Riemann sphere, stereographic projection, complex functions, complex derivatives, complex integrals, harmonic functions, conformal maps, line integrals, sequences & series, computing real integrals using complex analysis
A solid introduction to complex analysis -- from remembering the polar coordinate system to evaluating complex line integrals (and using tricks to make them easier).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Felt like a lot of interesting complex analysis topics ended up being skipped or not covered.
Excellent course. Content was cool. Very well explained. Only issue was the class lectures were pretty dry. Wanted more engagement by the prof.

This class starts off very slow. We spend almost 3 weeks on basic complex number ideas like complex functions. We also cover a lot of real analysis again. So, even though the pace at the end of the class is good, we only got to doing residues on the very last day. I think if we started the class a little bit faster, we could cover more. It would also have been nice to see more of the applications of complex analysis (for example to fluid dynamics or Fourier series). Also, having solutions posted for the homework problems would have been very helpful.

It felt like we were moving extremely slowly through the content at the beginning (ie spending non insignificant time on complex conjugates) but then sped up significantly at the end. Regardless, it was pretty doable overall. The grading of the problem sets was a little frustrating. We have not gotten a graded pset back since the midterm (and it is now after the final). Before the midterm, we were told the exam would cover only the psets that had already been graded, and then they released multiple grades within twelve hours of the exam.
Clear lectures and helpful office hours. Only weakness is that grading fell behind before the midterm and after the midterm, no problem set got graded.

This course could be improved by:
1. Not being at 9am
2. Having more proofs and less computation on the problem sets
3. Using a textbook that provides a bit more rigor and detail

The topic material is really interesting  there are tons of nice results from complex analysis, even relating to the reals, which makes it satisfying to study. The lectures were also not too fast; if anything I would say they were a bit on the slow side, especially for the first half of the semester. My main suggestion would be to make the test questions more similar to pset questions.
It would be great if we get our psets graded since we didn't get a single pset back after the midterm

Strengths: course was well taught, and theres a lot of nice material. The professor was also very nice.

Weaknesses: none other than maybe the textbook wasnt that good at covering some topics.

This course was honestly a little underwhelming. I think we spent too much time on the first few chapters of the book, which are mainly a review of complex variables/real analysis/multivariable calculus, and didn't even get to residues until the last week. I think that this course could have definitely moved a lot faster and covered a lot more.

Whether these are strengths or weaknesses depends on your own opinions, but I will note that the exams had basically no proofs on them at all and the homeworks were very light.

The course was quite good overall, with a reasonable workload, clear lectures, and great peer tutor office hours. The biggest weakness of the course was the textbook, which often had very poorly worded questions and sketchy proofs. The lectures sometimes also relied on these sketchy proofs, which was somewhat frustrating. We also received very little feedback on problem sets, with almost half of them left ungraded until after we had taken the final exam.

Several people I know in the course (including me) found lectures moved too slowly, and decided to learn exclusively from the textbook. The homework problems came from the textbook and didn't force you to really grapple with the material. Predictably, I didn't really internalize the material from this class---which lies on me---but I was not motivated/inspired to do so by the lectures.
The material felt a little rushed toward the end; this could be mitigated by spending less time on the first chapter of the text. Overall a solid course.
I thought the structure and pacing was good. I would have liked more feedback on problem sets I turned in.

Strengths: Content didn't feel super difficult, Professor Kenyon is a nice guy
Weaknesses: Couldn't understand lectures, probably better off reading the textbook than going to class. Didn't like how the class was structured. There was no ED discussion board to ask questions, barely any information about the exams (e.g. no practice exams, no idea what kind of questions would be on it, etc.). The worst part was that it was 9am in Watson Center and unrecorded -- that was unnecessarily painful

The lectures are easy to understand and all concepts are explained pretty well in class, and the psets are of reasonable length. One slight problem is the book we are using has some typos and could have been a bit better organized, so I wish we used a more well-established textbook for the course.
good pace

Strengths: Cool subject, decent lectures, good structure, helpful office hours.
Weaknesses: Midterm exam felt fast, "give the definition" questions on both exams were a little frustrating.

Strengths: course was well-paced, lectures were very clear-cut and easy to understand (lots of graphs!), you'll find concepts you may already have a great deal of familiarity with explained in new ways, super cool applications on psets which were not too easy, not too difficult (assigned textbook problems)

Strengths: Interesting material
Weaknesses: lectures were disorganized, midterm and final did not feel like it actually tested what we had learned, only one of two ULAs was actually helpful, did not receive helpful feedback on homework (and homework took over a month to get back)

Strengths: Prof. Kenyon cares about his students and keeps lectures relatively engaging. Homework was a good level of challenge and a good length (perhaps a little long took far longer than his suggested 3 hours a week to complete it).
Weaknesses: The textbook is VERY dry but was honestly necessary to be able to understand the material. Often, the content did not make sense in the lecture at all, but would after reading the textbook.
Strengths: manageable workload for a math class, fun material. Weaknesses: problem sets weren't graded until right before tests, and then were graded (mostly) on completion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend as an introduction to complex analysis, but not a particularly interesting or uninteresting course.
Yes. Take it. Good course!
Perchance.

Yes; complex analysis is an important subject that has some pretty cool results even for a non pure-math major. Extending things to the complex plane (such as residue calculus) seems particularly useful, and there are nice connections to physics as well.

Yeah, it was a pretty good math class  interesting results, not too hard to follow along. There were a few annoying psets (like lots of graphing functions or calculating coefficients for Laurent series, for example).
Yes
Yes! Complex analysis is a cool branch of math, and it's definitely worth taking for non-math majors, assuming you have some background in writing proofs

Maybe, maybe not. On the one hand, of course complex analysis is a very interesting subject. On the other hand, if Dr. Kenyon is teaching, then the lectures will be not very different from the textbook chapters. I also walked away not feeling like I'd really learned much complex analysis overall. Fortunately, Dr. Kenyon is generous with homework extensions. Speaking of which, although there were a couple homeworks that were egregiously long, most of them were very fair considering how computational many of the problems are. That's another thing: the course was much more computational than I was expecting (though of course proofs are still there). This was also reflected in the exams, which ended up being more difficult than expected.

Yes, its rather essential material that everyone should know, and its quite fun to learn. Its also not one of those courses that demands an unreasonable amount of time; you just do the homework each week which never took too long, and then prepared for the exam.

If you're looking for an easy/low effort math class for a 5th or 6th credit, take this. If you want to learn a lot of math, you are probably better off self-studying the material and taking 315 instead.
I would recommend this course. The content is very interesting, even if Professor Kenyon's proofs sometimes left something to be desired.

I'd recommend this course because the math has some neat, novel ideas that you don't really see anywhere else! But as a course, it wasn't great. If the math major ever changes to no longer have this as a core class, I wouldn't see a good reason to take it (unless you're specifically interested, in which case definitely do!).
Would recommend to all math majors! Complex analysis is a truly beautiful subject and one that every math major should at least know the fundamentals of.

Yes. I think Complex Analysis is a very cool subject and this course did a good job covering it. Might be nice to have taken 302 first (although I was fine without it) because a lot of the material is similar.
Only if required or if interested in complex analysis, wasn't particularly interesting for me.
Yes, it is a good introduction to complex analysis and helps you gain insight in any course that uses analysis.
good intro course to complex analysis

Yes, but with a different professor. The subject was great, and I appreciated a lot of the "beauty" that people talk about with this course. However, I felt that Kenyon's course administration was negligent in almost every way. There's about a dozen examples I could give, but here are a choice few:

Homework grading was a joke. At least half of it was based on completion, and the other half contained cryptic or even outright wrong comments. Most homeworks were not graded for at least a month after they were submitted. The final three homeworks (out of ten!) were never graded at all. No answer keys were provided. So, there was functionally no feedback in the course.

Kenyon also seemed to enjoy screwing us on exams. After the midterm, he said "based on what you've learned, I expected you to be able to do the first three problems." He did not give an explanation as to how we could've prepared for the other two problems, which required either pages of bashing (which Kenyon could not demonstrate upon request) or obscure magic tricks that only the math comp kids could figure out. So apparently understanding everything in the course only nets you a 60%. 

Kenyon also gave us an ungraded homework 11 to do over reading period "so that I can put this material on the final." The material in question was the most complicated and difficult of the whole semester, so we all spent a long time working through this homework and making sure we understood the concepts. Even Kenyon's final review session was mostly dedicated to going over the hw11. But of course, none of it was on the exam -- instead Kenyon opted for more of the obscure magic trick questions as a final "screw you".

There are many more things I would write about if I had the space. My feeling throughout the semester was that Kenyon is totally unaware of the consequences of his actions (or more often, his inaction). Seems that the people who actually need the help and support of a good prof really got left out this semester. Most of the top scorers in class never went to lecture, and our enrollment tripled on exam day. If you want a class where you work hard and are rewarded for it, please stay far away from Professor Kenyon.
Yes! Beautiful math, breaks your brain a little but in a nice way.

The content is kind of poorly taught. I felt really confused by certain topics, which I think aren't actually all that necessarily crucial to learning complex analysis. Maybe if taught through a different book, but Gamelin was a bit confusing at times, and the exams felt a bit too polarizing (questions were either trivial, or really tricky and difficult).
Yes, it's definitely a great stepping stone for pure math majors interested in analysis, found it gutsy compared to other 300 classes

With a different professor, yes. At moments throughout the course, I could see why I had heard complex analysis was great. I do not feel like the course helped me in seeing the greatness though. The lectures were pretty disorganized and sometimes hard to follow. I ended up reading every section of the book we went over and understood the material better. I think that many people did this as the class was at best 1/3 full during lecture. 

Kenyon did not seem to care about how the general population were doing in the course. One day during an especially hard homework week, he asked how the homework was going. When someone responded "awful" he simply giggled and started lecture. 

After the midterm he stated that he based on what he had taught us, he expected us to be able to do the first 3 questions. There were 5 questions on the exam. So, he was expecting us to get 60% at best from his teaching. This was extremely frustrating as someone who went to class, read the book, and went to office hours as I was not one of the people who could just intuit the last two questions on the exam.

Homework questions sometimes did not feel thought through. At one point Kenyon had to remove a question because he realized he hadn't taught us how to do it. Homework was not given back in a reasonable time frame. Before the midterm Kenyon stated that the exam would consist of homework 1-6 or all the homework up until that point that had been graded. Somewhere between 9pm-11pm the night before our 9am midterm homework 4-6 was graded. There was minimal feedback. Kenyon said that some of it was graded for completion. I realize this is possibly the graders fault but Kenyon graded both our midterm and final within 24 hours so I wish he would've helped on the homework grading.

Our last homework was optional but was strongly encouraged because the material was fair game for the final. The final review session Kenyon held was largely over that homework. There were no questions on the final over this homework. I spent an entire day of reading period learning material that did not help me on the final at all. Yes, it was cool but it put an immense strain on me.

We had two ULAs for this course. One of them was extremely helpful (which was very needed on some homeworks) and the other sat there and did not answer anyone's questions. When this second ULA was holding office hours the room was silent as no one wanted to ask for help.

Yes. If you want or need to take complex analysis, I'd take it with Kenyon. I did not understand the material during lectures and sometimes struggled to stay focused for the whole 75 minutes, but Kenyon cares about his students and his exams are fair game he doesn't try to trick you and truly wants you to have solid foundations. Complex analysis is interesting and the most I have enjoyed math since high school, however, I'm still not sure I fully understand it!

I would recommend this class! It was very enjoyable with a decent workload on each problem set. I was not overwhelmed by the beauty of complex analysis as I was told I would be, but it was fun nonetheless.
